aws::graph::propositions: # Piper PA-46-350P Aircraft Accident in Houston, Texas
The accident occurred in Houston, Texas.
The accident number was CEN15LA078.
The accident occurred on December 15, 2014, at 10:30 Local time.
The aircraft registration was N224JJ.
The aircraft was a Piper PA-46-350P.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The defining event was landing gear collapse.
There was 1 person on board with no injuries.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The pilot reported the airplane veered sharply left just after landing as the nosewheel touched the runway.
The pilot applied right rudder to correct the veer.
The airplane continued off the left side of the runway despite the pilot's correction attempt.
The airplane's nose landing gear collapsed.
The airplane came to rest in a grassy area 150 feet from the runway.
Examination of the airplane revealed a fractured engine mount in the area of the nose landing gear actuator.
The airplane's manufacturer had issued a mandatory service bulletin about 12.5 years before the accident.
The service bulletin included a 100-hour recurring inspection for cracks on the engine mount in the area of the nose landing gear actuator feet.
The latest version of the service bulletin was issued about 6 months before the accident.
Maintenance personnel had completed the service bulletin inspection during three previous annual inspections according to maintenance records.
There was no record that the service bulletin inspection was conducted during the last annual inspection.
The last annual inspection occurred about 6 months before the accident.
The accident is consistent with an uncommanded left turn during landing resulting from a broken engine mount.
Maintenance personnel likely did not inspect the engine mount during the most recent annual inspection.
Alternatively, maintenance personnel may have inspected the area but missed cracks that had likely developed on the engine mount.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Houston, Texas

## Accident Number: 
CEN15LA078

## Date & Time:
December 15, 2014, 10:30 Local

## Registration:
N224JJ

## Aircraft:
Piper PA 46 350P

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Defining Event:
Landing gear collapse

## Injuries:
1 None

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Analysis

The pilot reported that, just after landing and as the nosewheel touched the runway, the airplane veered sharply left. The pilot applied right rudder; however, the airplane continued off the left side of the runway. The airplane's nose landing gear (NLG) collapsed, and the airplane came to rest in a grassy area 150 ft from the runway.

The examination of the airplane revealed a fractured engine mount in the area of the NLG actuator. As a result of similar accidents, the airplane's manufacturer had issued (about 12 1/2 years before the accident) a mandatory service bulletin (SB), which included a 100-hour recurring inspection to determine if cracks had developed on the engine mount in the area of the NLG actuator feet. The latest version of the SB was issued about 6 months before the accident. A review of the airplane's maintenance records revealed that maintenance personnel had completed the SB inspection during three previous annual inspections; however, there was no record that the SB inspection was conducted during the last annual inspection, which occurred about 6 months before the accident. The accident is consistent with an uncommanded left turn during landing as a result of a broken engine mount. Based on the evidence and the events, it's likely that maintenance personnel did not inspect the engine mount during the most recent annual inspection or that they did inspect the area and missed the cracks that had likely developed on the engine mount.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

---
